entry.title: Diagnosis
entry.content:
In my last post, I pointed out that I think we should treat cancerous team members more like cancer and less like team members. Adrian correctly commented that being cancerous is a slider and not a check box. So, throwing out the easy to diagnose cancerous team member I'm currently working with, I thought it would be interesting to try and come up with some symptoms and warning signs that can help to diagnose whether your tumor is malignant or benign.
First, I want to draw a distinction between between unproductive and cancerous. Simply producing very little does not necessarily make you a cancer. For example, your gallbladder does not do much for you when healthy, but it's not until it starts causing you pain(and hurting other organs?) that you think about having it removed. I would argue that the costs of keeping an unproductive team member are enough reason to strongly consider getting rid of them, but I don't think they generally demand the urgency and immediate action that a cancerous team member often does.

Team Member is not participating in optional team activities
When it's a risk factor:
The person is MIA from most team activities. There are many legitimate reasons why someone is unable to participate: family commitments, other personal interests, and other work activities for example.
When it's a symptom:
The person is generally(but not specifically) critical of team activities. "Brownbag lunches suck" isn't constructive/helpful.
When you have cancer:
Everyone on the team breathes a sigh of relief when the person doesn't show up.

Team Member is disagreeable
When it's a risk factor:
The person stubbornly holds to their positions in spite of evidence to the contrary. All of us occasionally dig our feet in the sand, at least it indicates that we give a damn.
When it's a symptom:
The person won't present any reasons for their position. It's pretty hard to have a reasonable discussion with someone when they won't present their reasons for holding a position nor hear yours.
When you have cancer: Once a decision is made, the person refuses let it go, and brings it up continually.

Team Member is a distraction
When it's a risk factor: The person often distracts/interrupts another member of the team. Sometimes a team member needs a distraction to take a brief mental break or the distraction is a request for help.
When it's a symptom:
The person continually distracts/interrupts the entire team. Wasting one person's time is one thing, wasting the whole team's time is bigger problem.
When you have cancer:
The person continually distracts/interrupts the entire team in a rude manner with things that are off topic and/or not related to the task at hand.

Nobody knows what the Team Member is doing
When it's a risk factor:
The person's tasks are vague or not defined. Some tasks are hard to define/describe, maybe someone with more knowledge of the area can help them.
When it's a symptom: The person is slow to finish tasks and unable to share task status. Some tasks take longer than expected but hopefully not all of them. When a person is almost done for long periods of time it's definitely a smell.
When you have cancer: When the person finishes a task is generally when someone else needs to pick it up and spend a lot of time fixing it.

Team Member refuses to change
When it's a risk factor:
The person has trouble growing their skills and picking up new ones. Some people take longer to learn than others, if they're making an honest effort it should eventually pay off.
When it's a symptom:
The person simply mangles new thoughts and ideas to fit their current world view. With agile you need to create a first draft of your complete requirements quickly so you can get a couple iterations of work on it before having everyone sign off on it so we can start to design the architecture in detail...
When you have cancer: The person actively discourages others from considering new ideas and putting them into action.

I'm sure I've left out many signs and symptoms so please let me know of any that you think should be added to the list.

entry.title: Cancer
entry.content:
Imagine for a second that you have gallbladder cancer. You've had it for a few year now but it's recently been diagnosed. As far as you know the cancer hasn't yet spread to other organs but you wonder about it every day. After consulting doctors, and friends and family you've narrowed down your options: you can try and move the cancer to one of your lungs, at least then your gall bladder should start to function more normally, wait around and hope that a few massages in the area would turn it back into normal tissue, or simply do nothing and live with it. These options seem pretty ridiculous, but wait there's more. Now imagine for a second that you were paying $100k a year(not to mention maintenance cost) to keep that cancer. Furthermore, let suppose that the cost of surgery to remove it is very low with a very high probability of full recovery. Your selected set of options just went from silly to unbelievable. What reasons might someone have for refusing to have the cancer removed?
  1. The cancer has been around a long time. We've been living with it for a while. Why should we get rid of it now?
  2. The cancer might come around, we just need to give it a chance.
  3. Won't the other organs miss it when it's gone?
As silly as this sounds in a health care setting, anyone reading this most people figured out about two sentences in that I'm talking about a cancerous member of a software team. It's amazing how reluctant most businesses are to get rid of cancerous team members. Yes firing people is hard, but if you are not capable and willing to do it when necessary then you are doing yourself a disservice. People always seem to be worried about giving cancerous team members many chances to improve. As if magically on the seventh chance the person will turn it all around. We're not talking about people who are on the fence, or people who have just have had had a bad couple of weeks. Do we really owe chances to someone who has shown them self to be cancerous? Why? Is there really a chance that someone will go from being cancerous to being highly positive? What are the costs of doing this? What is the expected return on that investment?
